awd_titl_txt: Inspiring Innovation: Two-year College Geoscience Faculty as Agents of Change
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to serve the national interest by providing opportunities for geoscience, environmental science, and other STEM faculty to consider actionable changes that they could adopt, adapt, and implement in their instructional and other professional practices. To achieve this aim, a five-day virtual conference for two-year college (2YC) geoscience faculty will be held to advance knowledge about improving 2YC student success and becoming a faculty change agent. The conference will be led by individuals who have (1) served as faculty leaders (change agents) on their campuses and in their regions; (2) written articles in “Catalyzing Change: STEM Faculty as Change Agents” (Baer, Layou, & Macdonald, 2022), a volume of New Directions for Community Colleges, about their work as change agents; and (3) written funded grant proposals. This professional development experience will prompt faculty to consider how to improve their teaching, strategies for inclusion, and student mentoring skills. These changes will enhance the recruitment, retention, and support of STEM students at 2YCs. This conference will also address barriers to 2YC faculty involvement in NSF proposal conception and creation, and provide support, feedback, and time for participants who wish to develop grant proposals. Increased 2YC faculty participation in federal grants could have a tremendous impact on the recruitment and retention of a diverse group of STEM workers as many students at 2YCs are members of groups historically underrepresented in STEM.
 
Project leaders will convene a five-day virtual conference for 2YC geoscience faculty using articles from “Catalyzing Change,” most of which were authored by 2YC faculty who have led faculty professional development in the context of the SAGE 2YC (Supporting and Advancing Geoscience Education at Two-Year Colleges) program and/or have experience with funded grant proposals. Conference sessions — led by “Catalyzing Change” chapter authors — on effective teaching and student learning; diversity, equity, and inclusion; and supporting students’ career and transfer paths will disseminate the content of the “Catalyzing Change” articles and aid participants in formulating ideas for future work as faculty agents of change and grant proposal authors. The interactive format of the conference will aid a diverse group of participants, many of whom may be new to leading faculty professional development and/or writing grant proposals in the past, in formulating ideas for moving their work forward on their campuses and developing individual or collaborative NSF proposals. The goals of the project are to grow the existing community of 2YC faculty change agents across the country, continue to advance the goals of the SAGE 2YC project, and encourage increased 2YC geoscience faculty participation in the submission of NSF and other grant proposals. These efforts will ultimately contribute to student success as faculty enhance their professional practices. The NSF IUSE: EDU Program supports research and development projects and conferences to improve the effectiveness of STEM education for all students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: MT SAN ANTONIO COMMUNITY COLLEGE DISTRICT

por.por_cntn:
The 2023 virtual workshop, Inspiring innovation: Two-year college geoscience faculty as agents of change, provided a dissemination model for inspiring faculty to make changes in their teaching and explore grant possibilities. Using chapters from the 2022 New Directions in Community Colleges volume, Catalyzing Change: STEM Faculty as Change Agents (https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/toc/15360733/2022/2022/199) as a foundation for workshop content, the workshop aimed to extend the reach of the Supporting and Advancing Geoscience Education in Two-Year Colleges (SAGE2YC): Faculty as Agents of Change project; help 2YC faculty develop plans to catalyze change in their courses, departments, institutions, and beyond; expand the community of 2YC faculty working as change agents; and encourage increased 2YC STEM faculty involvement in grant proposals. In addition to the 5-day virtual workshop with sessions led by workshop leaders, 2YC faculty Catalyzing Change chapter authors, 2YC grant recipients, and NSF Program Directors, workshop participants (full-time and part-time 2YC geoscience and other STEM faculty) read and commented on relevant Catalyzing Change chapters. This strategy of reading and responding with an opportunity to talk to the authors enriched the communication during the workshop and helped establish a community of practitioners engaged beyond the Zoom sessions. The first three workshop days focused on effective teaching and student learning; diversity, equity, and inclusion; and supporting students' career and transfer paths. The final two workshop days aimed to move faculty work forward by providing participants with the opportunity to brainstorm project ideas, learn about funding sources and explore aspects of the proposal preparation process with other 2YC faculty and NSF Program Directors.

Participants learned about effective teaching and learning; diversity, equity, and inclusion; and supporting students' career and transfer paths by reading the relevant chapters and participating in interactive, engaging sessions facilitated by the chapter authors. They appreciated the references to teaching and other relevant websites and resources. They learned more about the grant proposal process and funding opportunities at the National Science Foundation. Participants appreciated time with 2YC faculty with successful grant experience and with NSF program directors. At the end of Day 5, many participants commented that meeting directly with NSF program directors was valuable and enlightening. The responses in the daily road checks and end-of-workshop evaluation indicate the value of community building and networking with other 2YC faculty. Participants gave the workshop an overall rating of 9.3 on a 1-10 scale.

The workshop provided an opportunity for the workshop leaders, session facilitators, and participants to explore topics of interest common across community colleges in relation to STEM education and student success. Strategies presented in chapters from Catalyzing Change were disseminated more widely; the participants were given open access to the relevant chapters, attended interactive, engaging presentations by the chapter authors (facilitators), and were given a chance to share their own expertise and ask questions in their responses to reading the chapters and within breakout groups. The sessions by 2YC grant recipients and NSF program directors inspired ideas for future work. Designed and led by 2YC faculty for 2YC faculty, the workshop elevated the discussion about the important role 2YC faculty play in the future of STEM education. The outcomes indicate the potential for this type of professional development to promote increased involvement by 2YC STEM faculty in change agent activities and external grant work. The Inspiring Innovation workshop provided an opportunity for 2YC faculty to develop as change agents and participate in a community dedicated to improving student success.

 


Last Modified: 06/28/2024
Modified by: Rebecca Walker
